How is Wool Made?

From the hillside pastures of Scotland to the spinning mills of Manchester, natural wool travels a journey of care and craft. This guide breaks down each step, revealing the art and science behind every fibre.

1. Shearing

Wool is harvested once a year when the fleece is at its finest. Skilled shearers use sharp clippers to remove the wool cleanly, ensuring the sheep’s comfort and maintaining the integrity of the fibres.

2. Cleaning & De-shedding

Once sheared, the fleece undergoes a rigorous cleaning process. Wet scouring removes lanolin, dirt, and other impurities. De-shedding tools remove the outer layer of hair, leaving a pristine fibre ready for carding.

3. Carding

Carding aligns the cleaned fibres into a loose, continuous web. This step prepares the wool for spinning by giving it a uniform texture and ensuring smoothness throughout the yarn.

4. Spinning

Spinners twist the carded wool into yarns of varying thicknesses. Modern spinning techniques maintain natural elasticity while reducing waste, ensuring each yarn is strong yet soft.

5. Knitting & Weaving

Yarns are transformed into fabrics using either knitting or weaving. Knitting produces a flexible, stretchable material, whereas weaving creates a structured, durable weave suitable for garments, blankets, and upholstery.

6. Finishing

The final stage includes washing, dyeing, and various treatments that enhance colour, softness, and durability. The finished fabric is then inspected for quality before it is shipped to manufacturers worldwide.
